campaign.story:
** Help us reach stretch goals: If we hit $6,000, we'll launch a website to keep the conversation going.**
Politics can be pretty divisive and depressing. What happened to hope? Too often, politics feels like a battleground where we lob accusations back and forth. And that's not likely to change after November's presidential election, no matter who wins or loses.
Politics have long been divisive and people will always disagree. But I have hope that we can do better.
So I'm launching this project to lift up stories of hope and joy among our elected officials. It starts with a book of political profiles, titled Better Politics, Please, that will tell encouraging stories of common ground. 
Yeah, that’s a tall order these days. 
But if we want to make civic engagement civil, it starts with we the people. I hope you'll join me in creating better politics, please.
Author Kevin D. Hendricks and Better Politics, Please! example book cover (illustrated by Carolyn Swiszcz).
The Book
We'll gather stories of 25 inspiring people to share in the book Better Politics, Please: 25 Stories of Politicians Who Value Hope Over Hate.
You can read some example profiles in our updates.
The book will feature leaders such as:
 Former U.S. Representative Carlos Curbelo: “If this country doesn't start healing, it is not going to matter who wins elections. We're all going to lose eventually.” Read more >> 
 U.S. Senator Tammy Duckworth: “As bad as it’s going to be in Washington, it’s never going to be as bad as getting blown up.” Read more >> 
 Brooklyn Park, Minn., Mayor Jeff Lunde: “The national dialogue, the rhetoric on both sides drives me absolutely crazy. That’s not how we do things in Brooklyn Park. We actually talk and listen.” Read more >> 
 Virginia Congressional Candidate Qasim Rashid: “I think the bigger risk is for me to stay silent and not try to neutralize this hatred. Because if I do that, as my children get older, they'll have to suffer through it.” Read more >> 
 U.S. Representative Jaime Herrera Beutler: "If you spend all your time sowing discord, that's what you're going to reap." Read more >> 
 Colorado Governor Jared Polis: “When we realize that our fates are connected and that we are better together, we can solve any problem we encounter.” Read more >> 
 Former Kentucky Lieutenant Governor Jenean Hampton: “I wasn't running to be first anything. I just wanted to help make Kentucky better.” Read more >> 
 North Dakota State Representative Ruth Buffalo: "I was never raised to see party lines. We’re all related, we’re all on the same team, we’re all human beings." Read more >> 
 U.S. Representative Adam Kinzinger: “I’ve gotten to the point where I don’t care about the politics...  What can we solve today?” Read more >> 
 Nevada State Senator Pat Spearman: "The women who are here this time, doesn't matter which party, when we're passionate about something we just push for it." Read more >> 
Minnesota State Senator Matt Little: “We will never heal our democracy hiding behind a keyboard.” Read more >>
These stories will come from both sides of the aisle and will offer a glimpse into that person and one small way they're bringing hope to politics. Some stories you might love, and some you might not. Some you’ll agree with, and some you won’t. But that's OK. Common ground isn't always comfortable. The goal of this project is to find something to celebrate in each person, no matter their party.
More than words, the book will also be illustrated by artist Carolyn Swiszcz. She's known for the zine Zebra Cat Zebra, which features her fun and quirky style. All the illustrations in the video above are her work. Carolyn will contribute illustrations for the cover and (initially) six interior illustrations that will help bring these profiles to life.  
American flag and artist Carolyn Swiszcz (illustrated by Carolyn Swiszcz).
Rewards
For most of the rewards, you get the previous rewards as well. So all the backers get a postcard! If you back at the $18 level or higher, you'll get a print copy of the book. In addition to the book, you get:
The knowledge that you brought this project to life—go you!
You'll get the book before the general public.
We'll print your name in the book, a permanent acknowledgment of your support and a big thank you. 
Your copy will be autographed by author Kevin D. Hendricks and artist Carolyn Swiszcz.
After this project is done the book will be available for sale to the general public, but the only way to get the above rewards is to back the project now.
Some of the higher tiers give you an opportunity to influence what goes in the book, from submitting quotes to picking who we profile (within reason—we reserve the right to veto ideas that don't fit the vibe of the book). You can also get an illustrated version of yourself by the talented Carolyn Swiszcz! (These higher reward tiers don't come with all the previous rewards, so pay attention to what's included.)
A Bigger Idea
This book of 25 profiles is the initial goal for this project. That seems possible and realistic in the midst of COVID-19 and unprecedented economic turmoil (gulp).
But I have a much larger vision. 
More than a single book, I'm envisioning a whole conversation. An ongoing project that collects and tells these stories through a website. But for that to happen, we need a lot of people to catch this same vision and support the project.
So we'll start with a book. Then we’ve got stretch goals to make the book bigger, add more illustrations, start a website, and more. But it can only happen with your help. 
It's Dot Com! (illustrated by Carolyn Swiszcz)
Stretch Goals
The initial goal to launch the book is $3,000. We hit that and the project is a go. But there's more we can do. As we hit these milestones, we'll do more:
 REACHED: $4,000 - Nice: We'll take things up a notch with professional cover design.
REACHED: $5,000 - More content! We'll expand the book to include 35 stories and 9 illustrations total.
 $6,000  - It's a website: We'll launch a dedicated website to continue telling these stories.
 $7,000 - Pro: We'll hire a designer to create a logo for the website.
 $8,000 - More more: We'll double the size of the book—we'll do 50 stories and 12 illustrations total.
 $10,000 - Steady content is what fuels a conversation, so if we hit this stretch goal we'll commit to doing at least one post per week on the website for the first six months after the site launches.
Why Now?
I’m launching this campaign in the midst of the COVID-19 outbreak. That seems foolish, and maybe it is. There’s an unusual level of fear and uncertainty, but there’s also an unusual level of people coming together and doing the right thing. Those are the stories I want to champion. 
We need this conversation now more than ever. Troubled times are exactly when we need better politics. 
Wearing your mask? (illustration by Carolyn Swiszcz)
Why Me?
Frankly, I wish it wasn’t me. For the past few months I’ve been telling people, 'I have this crazy idea—talk me out of it.' A few have told me it won’t work, but no one has said it’s a bad idea. Many have told me to go for it. So here goes.
I ran the church communication blog, Church Marketing Sucks, for 15 years. I saw firsthand the power of content to start a conversation and create a movement. I think the same needs to be done for politics.
Professionally, I’m in a bit of a transition. Church Marketing Sucks was a mainstay for most of my career, and now it's done. Not only am I feeling the loss of income, but there’s the loss of purpose. I’ve spent the past six months or so wondering what’s next. This might be it—or at least I’m willing to take my shot.
Where the Money Goes
Thousands of dollars in a Kickstarter project sounds like a lot, but there are a lot of expenses to cover:
 Fees: Kickstarter keeps about 10% (they keep 5% and about another 5% goes to credit card processing fees).
 Taxes: The government will keep another chunk (death and taxes, right?).
 Content: Creating the content will be a major expense. We need to pay illustrator Carolyn Swiszcz, and there's my time writing, editing, and proofing the copy. Then there's producing the print and digital versions of the book, with layout, design, and all the production work.
 Rewards: Delivering the rewards is another big expense. There's printing postcards and mini-prints, shipping, envelopes, and more. 
 Stretch goals: As we hit stretch goals, some of the income will go toward bringing on professionals to take things up a notch with quality design. Stretch goals will also pay for more illustration and writing time as we make the book bigger. If we launch a site, there's hosting, domain, building a site, etc.
If We’re Successful
If this works, we can start a conversation about better politics. Hitting the initial goal will create a book that tells stories of hope and joy in our politics—just in time for the 2020 election. 
If we hit some of those stretch goals, we can make the book better and even launch a website to keep this idea rolling. Because we need better politics not just in 2020, but well beyond.
I hope you’ll join me by backing this Kickstarter campaign. Let's start a conversation and celebrate better politics, please.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This project is an experiment to see if people will support this idea. It's a big risk, but I think we're up to the challenge.

I'm a full-time freelance writer, so creating content is what I do. I've already started writing profiles, and have more than 10 ready to go. I actually love writing these, so I'm eager to have the monetary support to keep doing it.

These projects always have unforeseen elements, but I've tried to be realistic in planning. There are minor risks of an act of God, my work situation changing, or other calamity. Though given that we're launching this in the midst of the COVID-19 shutdown, it seems like we've already faced big changes. If anything, this is a project that will help me weather this situation.

I've self published a dozen books for myself and others, so I don't anticipate any challenges there. I plan to write and finalize the book over the summer and have it ready to share by early fall.

Songs for the Sojourn - Bellwether Arts
In preparation for Holy Week Cardiphonia+Bellwether Arts is releasing Songs for the Sojourn. Music, visual and physical art and words designed to inspire, reconnect, invite, and clear space for the coming liturgical season rooted in the Psalms of Ascent (Psalm 120-134). 
The project will include:
A book of devotions for each psalm alongside original artwork.
Songs for the Sojourn-double disc.
Full songbook of chords and leadsheets. 
An original designed and screen-printed handkerchief for your liturgical journeys.
Each item can be bought separately or as an entire project while items last.
We are hoping to raise $12,000 in order to support the artists, create physical booklets of devotions and artwork, and to cover our production costs (mastering, art and design, manufacturing, etc).
Our goal is to have the whole project available DIGITALLY for your Holy Week devotions (March 26) and the physical materials sent out the week of April 22.
*Video by Blake Johnson, largely filmed in historic Dimnent Chapel on Hope College's campus.
*Cover image - Psalm 123 "Help Higher than the Hills" Aaron Collier
*Video music - Psalm 133 by Richard Kentopp (The Gentle Wolves)
---
The Past:
A number of years ago I was hunting through a used bookstore and stumbled upon a little book called "Ascent to the Cross" by Erik Routley. It was the published form of a lecture that walked through the Psalms of Ascents as a journey with Jesus from Palm Sunday to the cross.  The book struck me with two things - one that the psalms could have a liturgical anchor in the church calendar, and two that Jesus probably sang these songs as part his regular worshipping life during passover (and especially the last week of his life). 
Eventually this idea turned into a Calvin Worship Renewal Grant for my congregation in Raleigh where it blossomed into a year long meditation on the the ascent psalms.
The Present:
Finally after all of these years Cardiphonia, with the help of Bellwether Arts, is extending this project into something we hope will bless the worldwide church!  
The project is multi-faceted with music, visual, devotional, and liturgical components. Musicians have contributed over 30 new worship songs inspired by this group of psalms.  Visual artists have contributed an image for each psalm, and an eclectic group of pastors, scholars and writers have provided some guidance to worshipping through the ascent psalms. There will also be digital access to a full songbook and services inspired by each psalm. 
This project could never have happened without the tremendous gifts of the church coming together.  My deep gratitude to all of the artists listed below who contributed. 
The Future:
The whole project will be available digitally for Holy Week 2018.  Then in the following month or so we will get all of the cool physical rewards out to supporters (double disc, art/devo book, handkerchief, t-shirts, etc). 
We also hope to eventually take this project to Israel to support a youth summer arts camp sponsored by a local church, and we are in conversations with the missions agency Serge to direct some portion of the proceeds to support refugee care.
---

Carpool - A Short Film 
In Carpool, we join two women on their way to work but as they reach their destination, their work has massive implications.
I wrote this script last year after a conversation with lead actors, Gail Hafar and Jessie Busbee. We wanted to show two women in their 30's talking about normal work and life but also put them in a situation that I've never seen on film before. 
The final film should be about 6 minutes in length. 
I've been creating projects for the past decade and thought it would be incredible to try the Kickstarter platform for some financial helps in making this project a reality. No matter your level of financial help we'll be updating with our production immediately and give you quick links to our live broadcasts through the entire process.

campaign.story:
Hi, my name is Craig Wilson and I’m excited to tell you about THE ONE:SIX WORSHIP PROJECT. Above is my favorite picture of our band leading worship. The reason it’s my favorite, is you’ll notice the band is not in focus. Whenever we have the opportunity to lead our goal is to always make Christ the focal point of the worship and for our band to disappear and just become worshippers with everyone else.
I've been really fortunate to play with some guys who are not only great musicians, but really good friends. Guys like Josh Merold, Brian Kammer, Duane McDonald, Norm Wozniak, Paul Bogan and others too. Over the past several years we have had the privilege to lead worship at a number of retreats and conferences. Like myself a few of the guys are full time Pastors at churches. I love their heart for God, music and people. When we lead at places, we like to say “that often the best worship happens not on the stage, but off the stage when we get the chance to talk with people, pray for them and with them, and encourage them as they encourage us in return. Truth be known, we’re a lot more comfortable spending time with people, than under stage lights, wearing skinny jeans and trying to rock cool hair. Let’s be honest, NOBODY wants to see us in skinny jeans, and we haven’t had cool hair since the 80’s!
One of the things we run into when we lead at places is people asking us. “Do you guys have a CD recording or digital files?” The answer unfortunately has been “No, we don’t”. That is until now! Here’s where we need your help. We’re going to finally get into the studio and to record songs as well as take it to them to production, so we can have Cd’s and digital files for people to take with them. This will also help us get an opportunity to lead worship at more places. We've  had several people interested in having us out, but they always ask if we have recordings they can listen to before booking us.
What’s behind the name - ONE:SIX WORSHIP PROJECT? The reference is from Philippians 1:6 and the idea that God is not finished with any of us yet, we’re still a bit of a work in progress, a project if you will. Anything you contribute will go to the cost of the studio time, final mixes, as well as the cost of producing the Cd’s and getting the music digital ready. 
 I’m excited that we will be recording at “Ear Witness Studios” in Southern CA with Sam Knaak. He’s a friend of one of the guys in the band and in my brief interactions with him thus far, I get the feeling he’s an all around solid guy and we are looking forward to working with him! All the guys are passionate about music and I think we bring a little "Heart & Grit" to the style we play. You'll hear a lot of electric guitars and Hammond organ, with some rock and blues sensibility. We don't mind throwing a little bit of grease in the wheels, worship music doesn't always have to be pretty. We hope you will consider the opportunity to partner with us. Thanks for your support, and we hope you’ll get a chance to listen to it soon.

This record is an end and a beginning. A death and rebirth. A dream. This is my journey on the night sea. A place dark and uncertain. A beautiful place, alive with possibility. 
These songs are my honest gift to you. A continuation of my journey. Permission for you to be honest too. Permission for you to be.

Looptimus
The Best USB MIDI Foot Controller
Fund this project TODAY for $199
Retail price after Kickstarter ends is $299
It's here... finally a USB MIDI Foot Controller that is EASY to program, looks cool and JUST WORKS.
Too many controllers on the market are expensive, hard to program, hard to plug into your system. Looptimus is designed to solve all of these problems.
Now with a 5 PIN MIDI OUT JACK!
WORKS EASY WITH: Any MIDI capable software such as Ableton Live, MainStage, ProTools, Garageband, Reason, and many more!
Also works with Loop Community "PRIME", our FREE iOS App 
FEATURES:
20 Banks, A - F for each Bank
All-Access Bank for quick switching
16 MIDI Channel Options
1 Dedicated STOP button (single MIDI note)
9 Rock-Solid, Momentary switches
USB MIDI connection
5 PIN MIDI OUT JACK
Expression Pedal Jack (for Roland Rv-5 or equivalent)
3 Digit LED Display
USB Bus Powered!
9v optional power jack
Aluminum Enclosure, Black powder coated
6 ft. USB Cable included
8x5" x 5" x 1.5"

The Journey - How "Looptimus" Came To Be
September 2012
Matt was playing a concert in West Virginia and decided to name his computer Looptimus Prime. In his live performance, there is a segment where Matt has a full on "conversation" with his computer, Looptimus Prime. It's a 'tongue-in-cheek" concept, but entertaining... at least we think so :)
October 2012
Loop Community decides to build a FREE mobile App, and calls it "Prime"... knowing full well that a "Looptimus" product is coming.
December 2012
Loop Community investigates the idea of manufacturing their own pedal. Discussions begin.
January 2013
The Loop Community team decides that it's time to develop the best MIDI foot controller for live performance. We honestly got tired of selling a pedal (Soft Step) that is too hard to program. We also grew weary of receiving support request after support request on how to use the SoftStep. Frustrated users are not what we're after.... So Matt sketches up the first idea for "Looptimus" and meetings begin with various developers.
Initial Design Sketches
CAD drawings for the enclosure
January 2013
The pedal design is decided upon and the first silkscreen design is created and sent to the manufacturer for printing.
February 2013
The first prototype (steel enclosure) arrives and begins thorough testing in live performances throughout Chicago.
First Prototype (w/ a Steel Enclosure)
Road testing on stage!
April 2013
Meetings begin with large manufacturers, suppliers and assembly lines to discuss large-scale manufacturing of such pedal. Developers begin working on the custom circuit board design, which requires hours of testing.
Prototype Testing
May 2013
Further development takes place to tweak the pedal. An expression pedal jack is added to the pedal after user requests.
June 2013
The first 3 road-test prototypes arrive and are shipped to selected musicians across America for further testing.
First 3 Prototypes ready for user testing!
July 2013
Looptimus is seen "hiding-out" at the Loop Community booth for several national worship conferences around the country. Testing and tweaking continues with our professional team of developers and programmers.
hiding under the table!
On Matt McCoy's Pedal Board @ NWLC
August 2013
After discussing the many different enclosure options, we decide to go with a black powder coated, Aluminum enclosure for maximum durability and lightness in weight. All sides are rounded, with no sharp edges or screws showing. Designs, Manufacturer and Part Suppliers are finalized and READY TO GO! It looks beautiful.
(Artist Rendering) Actual Product will be in a Black, Powder Coated, Aluminum Enclosure.
MADE IN THE USA!!!

How Can I Use the Pedal?
The pedal has 20 banks + an all-access bank, available at any time. So that is actually a total of 21 banks.
One Bank Per Song
Use each bank for a song in your setlist. Then use each patch in the bank for a different section of your song. Each bank has A - F patches, so you can assign A to Verse, B to PreChorus, C to Chorus, etc. 
Use One Bank for your Setlist
Assign button A to song 1, button B to song 2, button C to song 3, and so forth
Use for Live Looper in Ableton
Assign buttons to the Live Looper settings in Ableton Live and loop your instrument live!
Get Creative!
Anything you can assign to a MIDI interface can be used with the Looptimus MIDI Controller
Get one of the few LIMITED EDITION colors, on KickStarter only!
Manufacturing Plan and Timeline
January 2013
Matt meets with a professional pedal developer to discuss the idea of "Looptimus". The pedal developer agrees to help us build our initial concept prototype.
March 2013
Matt begins to meet with numerous manufacturers around the United States to discuss the potential of mass manufacturing a pedal. Matt also talks with a manufacturer in China, but decides to keep all manufacturing in the USA for quality control and short delivery times.
April 2013
Loop Community partners with a large, accomplished and proven manufacturer in Chicago. Development begins on the pedal - bill of materials, CAD drawings, enclosure designs, PC board designs, etc. Coders begin developing the logic for the pedal that will be printed to our own custom chip and circuit board.
June 2013
Part suppliers are finalized and quotes are agreed upon. 
August 2013
The manufacturer and supplier of the Aluminum enclosure is secured. Screen-printing manufacturer is secured.
September 4 2013
KICKSTARTER BEGINS
October 2013
KICKSTARTER ENDS
Initial PO is placed and Aluminum Enclosures arrive in manufacturing facility 4 weeks later.
Circuit Boards, switches and other parts are ordered and shipped to assembly line. This will take no longer than 2 weeks.
November 2013
Enclosures arrive and are screen printed with the Looptimus logo and button labels. Pedals are assembled by hand in a professional assembly line. They are tested, packaged and ready for shipment.
December 2013 / January 2014
Pedals are shipped from warehouse to customers.

“Beauty is the seal of truth.” - Benedict XVI
Friends, I am hoping to record a new project of songs for the Church. I am newly independent after a stint at a record label, and it's so important to me to stay connected with the people (you) who have supported me and rooted for me through the years. And so I want to make a record of songs we can sing together--and I want to make it with you! If you believe in this idea, I invite you to support me financially, with prayer, and with sharing. There are a lot of great rewards you can check out--even if you can only give a dollar, there is a reward coming your way! Every dollar really does count. Now, more than ever, I can't do this without you.
I've spent several years artistically waffling between writing corporate worship music and Christian pop music. Recently I have come to realize that my gifting lies in leading worship more than it does in playing church concerts: and what's interesting is, as I look back even over any commercial success I've had, the most well-loved songs I've released are the ones that offer the opportunity for others to pray them along with me (Restless, You Revive Me, even Winter Snow.)
So with that in view, I am laboring both in prayer and in my art to make music that serves the Church in its various needs and purposes. Some of those needs may include personal devotion (like praying in your car), or Sunday worship, or corporate prayer (like a Friday night worship gathering). I grew up underneath the great banner of the Christian hymnal tradition, and so I have been writing some songs that draw from that heritage—but I am also influenced greatly by the charismatic renewal in the Church, and so some of the record may reflect that as well. Mostly I want to write something fragrant, and give it as an offering to God and to you. I want you to sing it with me. With your help, I can make this project happen.
This record will feature the piano and my vocals very heavily, with some added atmosphere. I want it to be simple and yet lush, in order to create a space where you and I both can pray without distraction. Liturgy is part of my background, and I am hopeful that some of these songs will be helpful in that setting.
I have long believed that true Beauty can change a world where truth and goodness are no longer important to most people. Beauty is still idolized in our society, and so it still has influence, however warped its role may have become. But the remarkable thing about true Beauty is that, when it is real and when it is pure, it carries in itself Truth and Goodness. The three are inseparable. And the best thing I can do as an artist who wants to serve the Church is to love all three, and to pursue them with prayer and humility, hoping to offer them to the Church and the world using the gifts I've been given. I believe God will bless that work. I am not worthy of it, but I undertake it willingly.
More beautiful than any gift of music one person can give is the coming together of believers to sing the praises of God. I hope this project will afford me the opportunity to experience that with you. Please consider supporting me: I have lots of fun rewards—I think you'll love them! And I hope you'll love the record. I am really excited to make music with you. :) Thanks for everything.

Hi, and welcome to our Kickstarter page, where you can be a part of setting the TENT back up. 
GREAT NEWS!! The tent is officially BACK UP! We've reached our goal and are beginning to book studio time and flights for Spence and Steve to Nashville. HOWEVER...please continue to spread the word because every extra dollar will help make this an even better sounding, better looking, better smelling project. For those of you donating at the $75 level and higher, here's a sneak peak at the t-shirt Dave has designed. In a couple of weeks, we'll be asking for your sizes (no need to send those in yet).
Where to begin? Let's start two years ago in Franklin, Tenn. We were rehearsing for a 10 year reunion show at a worship conference. Very soon after playing through a few songs, we starting talking about how fun it would be to record again but couldn't figure out how to pay for it. The answer to our quandary came with Kickstarter. We LOVE Kickstarter because the fans get to participate in the process and we don't owe a thing to a record label. Instead, we owe YOU, our fans and supporters...to whom we've always owed a great deal of gratitude. (awww...single tear)
There's literally NO PRESSURE on us. We have no obligations to labels, publishers, managers, booking agents...no one. Our only obligation is to YOU. With that in mind, our goal is to simply enjoy ourselves and make you proud.
So you're asking "Sheesh, $28,000 is a LOT of money." Yes it is. And we don't have it. But, if a lot of you give a little bit, we'll be ready to rock. 
The money we raise will be spent wisely, but it has to go a L-O-N-G way. Beyond things like recording studio rentals, producer and engineer fees, other musicians, mixing and mastering, we're also going to need funding to create artwork, do a photo shoot, duplicate the CD, fly Spence and Steve to Nashville, etc. We can assure you, this is a shoestring budget and we promise no caviar lunch jet rides. 
We've tried to come up with what we think are some fun awards for our backers, but mainly we wanted to make sure that you get your money's worth in downloads, t-shirts, Skype calls...even private concerts.
NOTE: In any particular level, you can donate more dollars. For instance, if you want the awards at the $50 level, but really want to give $1,000...you can do that.  We see no problem with that whatsoever. Honestly. 
BUT...there's good news and not-so-good news. The good news is that if we raise OVER our goal, we get to keep the extra funds. That means higher quality everything, plus the ability to hire a publicist, maybe hire a radio promoter, print up some new merchandise, revamp our old touring gear, etc. Now, the not-so-good part: If we don't raise the TOTAL amount of our goal, we get ZERO. Nada, zilch, nothing. No CD, no reunion shows, no caviar lunches on private jets. That's a sad thing, right? Right.

Thanks for stopping by! Here's the scoop about a new project I've got in the works...
Recently there's been an awakening in my creative life that I'm excited about. New songs have been stirring in me, and I'm ready to record a new album called Everything You Love Comes Alive. 
This past year I've been writing and speaking about discovering our gifts, developing and nurturing them with passion and discipline, then sowing them like seeds into the fields where we live and work. I believe this "work of art" isn't so much a list of accomplishments or failures as it is doing what we love and are passionate about, and finding beauty and purpose in our lives as a result. Some of the songs on this record echo that theme--I can't wait for you to hear them!  
Producing the album will be Nate Sabin, who produced my last CD, Meteor Shower. He's a brilliant songwriter, producer and friend who helps inspire my best work. Our plan is to record in Nashville and Minneapolis in late Spring of this year. I want to bring all of the resources, talents and heart I possibly can to this project. 
As an independent artist, I don't have a record label that finances my albums, which means I am responsible for all of the costs. Although we've set the goal here at  $12,000, we've estimated the new album will cost about $20,000 to make. Even in a healthy, thriving economy, this amount is a lot to set aside and I'm very much in need of some help to fund this record. In addition to renting studio space, and paying the musicians and engineers a fair wage for their time and talents, there are also design and manufacturing costs. We were modest in our goal amount because it's all or nothing: if we don't get all of it pledged in the 30 days, we're back at zero.
I would be humbled and overjoyed to have you share in this creative endeavor with me. Your support will make this vision a reality, and you'll play a part in not only creating a beautiful work of art, but also in encouraging and touching the lives of those who hear it. How cool is that?
I'm offering thank you gifts for your pledge, but mostly I want you to know from the deepest place in my heart that I am grateful for your friendship and support.  
Please contact staci@stacifrenes.com if you have ANY questions about this campaign or project! 
Warmly,
Staci

By age 13 Emilie was singing and playing with her musician dad in front of hundreds of people as a member of the church rock band. She not only has a passion and dream for music, but an emerging gift more than ready to be taken to the next level.
Emilie was mentored in songwriting by Grammy nominated artist Sarah Kelly who helped Emilie write some of her very first songs. Now, this project will allow Emilie to grow even more.

As a producer he recently recorded artists such as Sara Overall and the 1211 Band and is also credited on albums as a session drummer by artists including Black Eyed Peas, Pat Benatar, Paul Oakenfold, Buckethead, Katie Rose, Alannah Myles, Michael Brooke, and Glen Phillips. Ramy has coached and mentored dozens of very gifted artists so this recording will be a huge win for young Emilie. 
Dreams are possible, but they never come free. Help Emilie live her dream! The message is simple: life works best when we do it God's way as revealed in the Bible. What if the brokenness, the struggles, the confused morality, the sexual desperation around and within us can be healed? What if a hard look at Jesus provides authentic answers to life's toughest questions? It's not about religion, it's about Jesus.
What if some of life's biggest questions didn't have to stay questions forever?
Your backing will...

3. Pray that God will use this project to speak his own four letter word of LOVE over a culture that has lost its way.
From the Christian perspective, the world's crying need is a return to God. But our friends won't do that until their objections are answered. FOUR LETTER WORDS speaks to the touchy ideas that our ultra-tolerant age can't tolerate about Jesus. With love and patience, this book dismantles the disbelief that keeps our friends from God.
No system of faith or truth has ever offered as beautiful, logical and satisfying a worldview as biblical Christianity. It's time to say so, with compassion, humility, and courage.

1. FOUR LETTER WORDS --Why do Christians believe stuff that gets them into trouble? Why can they seem so intolerant? Why does our ultra-tolerant culture find the Christian worldview so intolerable?
2. TRUE --Who says your truth has to be my truth too? Can’t we both be right? What is truth and where can I find it?
3. KNOW --How do we know what we know? Is faith a weak link in the Christian’s chain of knowing? Doesn’t science contradict the Bible?

8. DAMN --Is hell real? Will God send people there? Why? How can hell be consistent with God’s love? Doesn't love win in the end? (You can download this chapter for free by clicking here.)
9. WAIT --Sexuality is a normal part of life, so, if we love each other, why wait? Wasn’t the Bible written for a different time and place? Why should we enforce its ancient values today?
